title: The crimes and court cases that shook Bury in 2024
body_text:
As 2024 draws to a close, we are taking a look at some of Bury’s most high-profile and shocking crimes and court cases to happen in the borough this year.
There have once again been a range of crimes that have taken place across the borough and cases dealt with in the corridors of justice.
March- Spate of stabbings despite arrival of the 'Knife Angel'
The 27ft sculpture, the "Knife Angel", which aims to raise awareness of the devastation caused by knife crime, arrived in Bury at the start of March.
But on Monday, March 11 there was a triple stabbing near Bury Market.
Also on that day, police were called to reports of a stabbing in Malton Avenue in Whitefield where a "male was found to have injuries that were not life-threatening".
Two days later, on Wednesday, March 13, police were sent to Whitefield Metrolink stop at around 11pm after an "offender" lunged at someone with a knife, during which no injuries were reported.
And on Thursday, March 14 in Parkhills Road, Bury, a 40-year-old man and three 16-year-old boys were arrested on suspicion of violent disorder, following an altercation. Police say no serious injuries were reported.
Following the incidents, police imposed section 60 stop and search powers across large parts of Bury and Whitefield, and across the Metrolink system.
A section 60 authority grants police powers to search people in relation to criminal investigations.
March- Fatal stabbing of teenager in Whitefield
Later in the month, on March 28, Coby Tristram, 18, was stabbed following an altercation in Abingdon Avenue, Whitefield.
He was taken to hospital after being stabbed in the arm and died two weeks later.
Shams Benda, 18, of Victoria Grove in Bolton, alongside his three co-accused, Charlie Harrison, 21, of Mather Avenue in Whitefield, a 17-year-old boy and a 16-year-old boy who both cannot be named, were sentenced at Manchester Crown Court in November following a trial in October.
Two of the co-accused, Charlie Harrison, and the 17-year-old, were charged with violent disorder and, respectively, possession of a bladed article and possession of an offensive weapon.
Benda and the defendant aged 16 were also both charged with possession of an offensive weapon.
The 16-year-old boy stood trial accused of murder and an alternative count of manslaughter, while Harrison, Benda and the 17-year-old boy were accused of manslaughter.
However, following legal submissions by their defence teams, a judge ruled that a jury could not safely convict the four.
March- Former Manchester City FC employee netted more than £180,000 in fraud
March saw Craig Hookham, 39, sentenced after he defrauded more than 50 people into believing they were buying concert tickets and football match tickets.
Hookham, of Medlock Way, Whitefield, worked at Manchester City Football Club, Sale Sharks and Salford Red Devils and gained an excellent working reputation for sourcing tickets for hospitality events.
The fraud was only uncovered when one of his victims became suspicious after the events, he had bought tickets for kept being postponed.
Hookham pleaded guilty and was sentenced to two years and four months.
April- Shock as human remains found in Kersal Dale
It was this month when the shocking discovery of body parts was made in Kersal Dale, near Prestwich.
A torso was found in clear plastic by a passer-by at Kersal Dale Wetlands, on April 4.
It was later discovered that the remains were that of Stuart Everett, 67, from Salford.
May- Man found not guilty of manslaughter after man attacked on night out
An amateur boxer who punched a dad-of-one on a night out in Bury town centre was found not guilty of his manslaughter.
Brook Marshall-Byrne, 20, was on trial at Manchester Crown Court after attacking 35-year-old Piotr Ludwiczak on Silver Street in the early hours of July 8 last year.
Mr Ludwiczak suffered serious head injuries after hitting the pavement following the blow and later died in hospital.
Marshall-Byrne’s defence had argued he was acting in self-defence after “trouble had grown” between groups of revellers on Silver Street after bars closed for the evening.
The jury delivered a unanimous verdict of not guilty following three days of deliberation.
Brook Marshall-Byrne, of Prestwich Hills, was sentenced after admitting to affray after evidence of fighting in May last year emerged and he was convicted of another count of the same offence for the fatal July incident.
June and July- Sisters on trial after helping brother flee justice in Cole Kershaw case
Sisters Farah and Husna Khan went on trial accused of helping their brother Khayam Ali Khurshid evade justice.
Khurshid was involved in the murder of teenager Cole Kershaw in August 2020 where he was shot in the chest after being pursued by a car on Chesham Road.
The sisters were on trial at Manchester Crown Court for allegedly trying to get their brother to Pakistan before being arrested.
Following the trial, both sisters were found guilty.
Detective Inspector Marc Barker from the Serious Crime Division said: “It has been just over four years since the fatal attack, and our goal has always been to provide answers and some sense of justice for Cole’s family and friends.
“This was an extensive investigation, but I am pleased that all those involved in this cowardly attack are now behind bars.”
August- Girl strip searched unlawfully at Bury Police station, Baird Inquiry
The Baird Inquiry, an independent review into the experiences of women and girls in Greater Manchester Police custody, was released.
And among the damning findings, the inquiry found that a girl was strip-searched unlawfully at Bury Police Station while she was under 16 at the time.
GMP Chief Constable Stephen Watson apologised for the findings in the report, and said the force would fully implement the recommendations from Dame Vera Baird.
September- Teenager destroyed evidence after stabbing dad-of-three
On Boxing Day 2022, 31-year-old Tyron Riley was found dead in Clarendon Park in Salford after being stabbed.
Bradley Waters, 18, from Prestwich, was sentenced for perverting the course of justice and conspiracy to supply heroin.
He said he stabbed Mr Riley in self-defence after saying Mr Riley initially attacked him.
However, Judge Nicholas Dean said: “Opportunities were lost to police because of your actions. The investigation into Tyron’s death was not as full as it could have been.”
September- Thug attacked grandad after row over electric bike
A thug was jailed after fatally punching a "wonderful" grandad in Bury town centre following a row, which broke out about the attacker riding an electric bike on the pavement across the road.
Michael Dawson, 78, had been out with a friend at The Bank pub on Market Street on the night of August 24 last year with staff saying he was in a “convivial mood”, but not drunk, when he left the premises just before 11.50pm.
At Manchester Minshull Street Crown Court, CCTV footage was played in court which showed Mr Dawson leaving the pub and walking on Market Street before pointing towards Nathan Pilling, who was riding an electric bike on the pavement on the other side of the road.
Pilling then rode across the road, got off his bike and put it against a rail and then stood directly in front of Mr Dawson as a confrontation took place.
During the argument, Pilling, who was aged 23 at the time, twice moved away to leave but when he returned for the final time he punched Mr Dawson to the head, causing him to fall to the ground, where he became motionless.
Mr Dawson was taken to hospital where it was found he had suffered a fractured skull and bleed on the brain and transferred to intensive care.
His brain injuries were discovered to be “irreversible” and life support was switched off on September 4 last year.
Prosecutor Francis McAtee said Pilling pleaded not guilty to manslaughter.
But he changed his plea to guilty on the first day of the trial.
Judge Tina Landale sentenced Pilling to five years and four months.
October- Man found guilty of murdering his mum
This month, Stephen Ball, 32, was accused of murdering his mum.
He was arrested after his mum Susanne Galvin was found badly injured at their shared flat on Pear Avenue in Bury in September last year.
Ball had pleaded guilty to manslaughter but he was on trial at Bolton Crown Court for murder.
Following a week-long trial, the jury found him guilty.
November- Ball receives life sentence for murder
He has been at Ashworth High Secure Hospital receiving treatment for schizoaffective disorder.
December- Police raid cannabis farm found over two floors in Bury
Around 300 plants were seized, and the officers had acted at this site from "intelligence gathered from within the community".
Officers believe that the warrant could be "linked with West Balkan’s organised crime groups and are investigating additional lines of enquiry".
New district commander Chief Superintendent Kirsty Oliver was present at the warrant.
